text: uh let's take you to the philippines now
where the number of people who have died
after a super typhoon hit last week has
risen to more than 375
we've heard from the red cross saying it
is carnage in many areas no power no
communication very little water the
typhoon has caused extensive damage to

there live we can join our philippines

managed to get there he joins me on the

communication issues howard how are
things there
yeah that's right lucy communication
here tonight i can see just opened me
the philippine red cross offering their
satellite phones to people here so that
they can call loved ones it's pitch
black here you can hear maybe the path
of the generator in the background
there's no electricity here in the city
and i'm standing in an area that was
normally a buzzing surface paradise it
was voted by conde nastus island as one
of the best island destinations in asia
this year and now it resembles a ghost
town you can see trees eerily without
leaves on them lit up by the low lights
that are running off the generators
tonight but today moving around the
island i spoke to many people who were
forced into tears because of the
experience that they went through when
they relived when the storm hit they
said it was an awful experience they
were terrified with their children
towering next to them and many people
have been telling me that they're
worried about water supplies here
particularly some people have been
getting diarrhea and stomach issues
because the water they're pulling up
from the wells
is no longer drinkable so they're
they're appealing for more water more
food and for the electricity to be fixed
so that the communications can come back
as soon as the electricity is back up
so how it is any aid getting through and
if so how are they getting it to chicago
aid is getting through but not enough uh
right now what we're seeing is these uh
planes coming into the airport but not
enough at the moment we saw today a
c-130 philippine air force plane coming
in around 100
or so tourists were
waiting outside when i arrived they were
desperate to leave um the charcoal they
they are worried that there won't be
enough food supplies in the days and
weeks ahead
in fact i spoke to the
regional governor and he told me he
feels that the power could be down for

only a certain limited number of planes

what's happening on charge but are there

you know we just don't know what is

been
absolutely i mean this is such a
complicated geography
how this storm moved across the
philippines that's more than seven
thousand islands this hit nine of them
and even on this island there are areas
that haven't been reached yet so the
full extent of this storm as is
reflected in the growing death toll is
only becoming clear as the days go on
and people venture further afield into
different islands and different spaces
to find out how people are doing here we
heard one island just off sugar island
there were people living off coconuts
because they didn't have enough food to
